meanings.definition: A small pile or heap of something, especially of loose stones or debris.
meanings.sent1: I saw a rickle of colorful leaves by the tree.
meanings.sent2: The children built a rickle of sand at the beach.
meanings.sent3: The squirrel made a cozy nest using a rickle of twigs.
meanings.sent4: The books on the shelf formed a rickle, ready to topple.
meanings.sent5: The rickle of coins on the table shimmered in the sunlight.

meanings.definition: To form into a pile or heap.
meanings.sent1: She began to rickle the fallen leaves into a neat pile.
meanings.sent2: Please rickle the toys into a corner before bedtime.
meanings.sent3: The chef will rickle the chopped vegetables into a colorful salad.
meanings.sent4: He rickled the papers on his desk, trying to find an important document.
meanings.sent5: The workers will rickle the bricks to start building the wall.

meanings.sent1: The old bridge started to rickle in the strong wind.
meanings.sent2: The tower began to rickle as the foundation weakened.
meanings.sent3: The jenga tower started to rickle as more blocks were removed.
meanings.sent4: His confidence started to rickle when he faced a difficult challenge.
meanings.sent5: The relationship began to rickle when trust was broken.
